questions.text:
1. A 36-year-old multipara presents with a blood picture showing hypersegmented neutrophils and typical pencil cells. MCV is normal. This condition is managed by supplementing:

1- Folic acid 2- Iron 3- Vitamin B12
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation most likely indicates a case of dimorphic anemia, and such cases are managed by supplementation with iron, folic acid, and vitamin B12. 

The given histopathological picture shows pencil cells, which are indicative of iron deficiency anemia, and hypersegmented neutrophils, which suggest folic acid or vitamin B12 deficiency anemia. MCV is generally low in iron-deficiency anemia, while it is high in cases of megaloblastic anemia secondary to folate and cyanocobalamine deficiency. Thus, a normal MCV excludes both these conditions individually and is more likely to favor a combination of both. This patient most likely has dimorphic anemia due to coexisting iron and folic acid deficiency. 

Nutritional anemia, which is an important cause of dimorphic anemia, is a significant problem worldwide. Blood pictures in dimorphic anemia will have features of both iron-deficiency anemia and folic acid–deficiency anemia.

Blood picture in iron-deficiency anemia:

* Microcytic hypochromic RBCs

* Presence of poikilocytosis in the form of characteristic pencil cells

Blood picture in folic acid/Vit B12–deficiency anemia:

* Hypersegmented neutrophils

* Macrocytic RBCs

questions.text:
2. A middle-aged female presents to the gynaecological OPD with a history of lower abdominal pain, fever and vaginal discharge. She gives a history of long-term usage of IUD. The cytological finding of the discharge shows the following finding. What will be the most appropriate management for this patient?

IUD- Intra-uterine device
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation with associated long-term IUD use and the cytological findings of clumps of ink blot or cotton wool-like filamentous organisms suggest pelvic inflammatory disease by actinomyces, and the drug of choice is intravenous penicillin.

The most common aetiological agent is Actinomyces israeli, which is a gram-positive, anaerobic, filamentous, non-acid, fast bacilli. High-dose parenteral Penicillin G or amoxicillin for 4-6 weeks, followed by oral Penicillin V for 6- 12 months, is the treatment of pelvic actinomyces.

Actinomyces is commonly found in the vaginal flora of IUD users. An increase in duration of use increases the colonisation causing chronic PID presenting as lower abdominal pain, fever, vaginal discharge, bleeding and weight loss.

Pearl PM1174: Treatment of choice in chronic PID

Patient characteristics

Choice of surgery

Young woman

Conservative surgery or Salpingectomy or Salpingo-oophorectomy

When extensive damage precludes conservative management

and

When the patient is multiparous and of an older age group

Abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

Mild case of PID adequately treated

and

Minimal damage but the infection may lead to infertility

Tuboplasty


Pearl PM1173: Organisms Responsible for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

Sexually transmitted: Gonococcus, Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Trichomonas  Aerobes: Staphylococci , Streptococci ,E. coli

Anaerobes: Bacteroides fragilis, Peptococcus, Clostridium, Actinomyces (IUD)

Others: Tubercular salpingitis

questions.text:
3. A 6-year-old boy was referred after a physician noticed yellowish discoloration of his eyes at a school health checkup. On examination, no signs of liver failure were seen, however, there was mild hepatosplenomegaly. Ultrasonography of the abdomen revealed no abnormality. Liver function tests are shown below.

Serum bilirubin 2.4 mg/dL (Unconjugated 2.2 mg/dl, Conjugated 0.2 mg/dl) AST 32 IU/L ALT 16 IU/L ALP 100 IU/L Albumin 4.2g/dl Globulin 2.4g/dl

Identify the correct Van den Bergh reaction that will be seen in this case.

choices.text: Colour develops in the presence of methanol
Colour immediately on addition of the reagent
Colour produced immediately intensifies on addition of methanol
No colour produced on addition of the reagent

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Gilbert's syndrome, and Van den Bergh reaction gives indirect positive due to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Van den Bergh reaction is a colorimetric method to measure the serum bilirubin level. The reagent diazotized sulfanilic acid (sulfanilic acid in HCl and sodium nitrite) reacts with bilirubin to form a purple-colored complex, azobilirubin. The reactions are shown below.

Clinical condition Reaction with reagent Interpretation
Normal serum No reaction Negative
High conjugated bilirubin
eg: Obstructive jaundice		 Colour produced immediately, without the addition of alcohol Direct positive
High unconjugated bilirubin
eg: Hemolytic anemia		 Colour produced only on the addition of alcohol  Indirect positive
High conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin
eg: Hepatic jaundice		 Colour produced immediately, intensifies on the addition of alcohol Biphasic reaction


 

Gilbert’s syndrome is the most common inherited disorder of bilirubin metabolism. It is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait where there is reduced UDP-glucuronyl transferase enzyme. The plasma bilirubin is usually less than 6 mg/ dL and the LFTs are otherwise normal. There is no bilirubinuria because the hyperbilirubinemia is predominantly unconjugated. The condition is not associated with liver injury and thus has an excellent prognosis, needs no treatment.

Pearl PM1482: Hereditary Hyperbilirubinemias

Disorder Inheritance Defects in bilirubin metabolism Clinical course

Unconjugated Hyperbilirubinemia

      

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I

AR

Absent UGT1A1 activity

Fatal in the neonatal period

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II

AR

Decreased UGT1A1 activity

Generally mild,

occasional kernicterus

Gilbert syndrome

AR (common)

AD (occasional)

Decreased UGT1A1 activity

Innocuous

Conjugated Hyperbilirubinemia

      

Dubin-Johnson syndrome

AR

Impaired biliary excretion of bilirubin glucuronides due to a mutation in canalicular multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP2)

Innocuous with black pigmentation of liver

Rotor syndrome

AR

Decreased hepatic uptake and storage

Decreased biliary excretion

Innocuous

questions.text: 4. A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester presented with tense periumbilical blisters preceded by severe itching for the past week. Direct immunofluorescence of the perilesional skin reveals linear C3 deposition along the dermoepidermal junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of pruritus, along with the presence of blisters in the periumbilical region during pregnancy, clinches the diagnosis of pemphigoid gestationis.

Pemphigoid gestationis is an autoimmune, bullous disorder that presents mainly in late pregnancy or the immediate postpartum period. Severe itching can occur before any skin lesions become apparent. Initially, erythematous urticarial papules and plaques typically develop on the abdomen, characteristically involving the periumbilical region, and later progress to tense blisters, resembling bullous pemphigoid. Complement-fixing IgG antibodies against BP 180 antigen of the hemidesmosomes at the dermoepidermal junction are responsible for the linear immunofluorescence.

Other options :

Option A: Although bullous pemphigoid can cause tense blisters with linear immunofluorescence, it presents in the older age group. The history of pregnancy and involvement of the umbilicus make the diagnosis of pemphigoid gestationis more likely.

Option B:  Polymorphic eruption of pregnancy is another pruritic inflammatory condition affecting pregnancy. It typically starts on the abdomen, often within the striae distensae if present, with severely pruritic urticarial papules that coalesce into plaques, spreading to the buttocks and proximal thighs. However, it spares the umbilicus and never develops into blisters. Direct immunofluorescence is usually negative.

Option D: Atopic eruption of pregnancy is a benign pruritic disorder of pregnancy that includes eczematous and/or papular lesions in patients with an atopic diathesis, once the other dermatoses of pregnancy have been excluded. It affects typical atopic sites such as the face, neck, and flexural surfaces of the limbs. Immunofluorescence studies are negative.

questions.text: 5. A young woman is undergoing evaluation for infertility. Her cervical mucus sample shows the following appearance on microscopy. She had her menstrual period 22 days ago. Which of the following inferences can be drawn from this finding?

choices.text: This finding occurs due to progesterone
The woman is in mid luteal phase

questions.solution:
The presence of a fern pattern on the 22nd day of her menstrual cycle indicates that she has not ovulated. 

Estrogen makes the cervical mucus thinner (option D) and more alkaline to promote easy survival and transport of sperms. When the mucus is spread on the slide, it shows the fern pattern (Option B). After ovulation and during pregnancy, the levels of progesterone rise, and this hormone thickens the cervical mucus. The ferning pattern will no longer be seen. 

The mucus is thinnest at the time of ovulation due to the increased levels of estrogen. It can be stretched into a long, thin thread that may be 8–12 cm or more in length. This is called the spinnbarkeit phenomenon.

 The tests for ovulation are:

* The body temperature decreases during ovulation by 1/2°F. Thereafter, it increases by 1/2 to 1°F due to the thermogenic action of the progesterone.

* Endometrial biopsy is usually done 1-2 days before menstruation. The presence of secretory changes in the endometrium suggests that ovulation has occurred. 

* Fern test- Appearance of fern pattern is seen before ovulation. After ovulation, the progesterone thickens the cervical mucus leading to the loss of fern pattern.

* Ultrasound- It is used to monitor the maturation of the Graafian follicle and ovulation.

Hormonal studies

* Increased levels of plasma progesterone (~15 ng/mL) in the mid-luteal phase (22–23rd day) suggest that ovulation has occurred.

* Determining the LH surge by urine or blood levels.





Other options: 

Option B: Ferning occurs due to estrogen, not progesterone. 

Option C: Mid-luteal phase occurs in the second half of the cycle or post-ovulatory phase. Estrogen predominance indicates anovulation and is hence in the follicular phase. 

Option D: Thinning of cervical mucus occurs due to estrogen. Thickening of cervical mucus is seen with progesterone.

questions.text: 6. Anxious parents brought their infant to the pediatric outpatient with complaints of an abnormal increase in the size of his head. Investigations revealed hydrocephalus due to the vein of Galen malformation. Identify the great vein of Galen in the image below.
questions.solution:
The great vein of Galen is marked as '1' in the image given above.

The great cerebral vein (of Galen) is a short median vessel, formed by the joining of the internal cerebral veins. It then curves sharply up around the splenium of the corpus callosum and opens into the anterior end of the straight sinus, located along the junction between the falx and the tentorium cerebelli.

Clinical significance:

* Vein of Galen aneurysmal malformations (VGAM) is the most common form of symptomatic cerebrovascular malformation in neonates and infants.

* Vein of Galen malformation can result in hydrocephalus, heart failure, or rarely, hemorrhage.

* There may be the absence of great vein of Galen in some congenital disorders.

The other veins marked are shown in the image below:

questions.text: 7. A 36-year-old female presented with amenorrhea, nausea, and vomiting. She was apprehensive about being pregnant after having unprotected sex. She gave a history of having undergone tubal ligation 8 months ago and admitted to having a low mood following it. On examination, her breasts were enlarged with pigmented areola. The abdomen was distended, and a pigmented line was observed from the umbilicus to the pubis. The urine pregnancy test was negative, and the pelvic ultrasound was unremarkable. What would be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The given history of amenorrhea presently and tubal ligation 8 months ago, clinical findings of breast enlargement and linea nigra, along with a negative pregnancy test point towards a diagnosis of pseudocyesis for which psychotherapy is recommended. 

Pseudocyesis is characterized by the presence of the classic symptoms of pregnancy- amenorrhea, nausea, breast enlarge­ment and pigmentation, abdominal distention, and labor pains, in a nonpregnant woman. It signifies the ability of the psyche (mind) to dominate the soma (body).

A true somatic delusion may be present in the patient but it is usually resolved after a negative urine pregnancy test result or pelvic ultrasound. Predisposing factors like a pathological wish or fear of pregnancy, gender or sexuality-related conflicts, and a history of miscarriage or tubal ligation, are usually present.

Management involves psychotherapy during or after such a presentation, to determine the underlying psychological abnormality and treat it.

Note: Couvade syndrome is a related phenomenon seen in some cultures where the would-be-father undergoes simulated labor. However, in those cultures, couvade is a normal phenomenon.

questions.text: 8. A 20-year-old female patient who is known to have polycystic ovarian syndrome comes with complaints of excessive facial hair as shown below. Which of the following is an androgen receptor antagonist that can be used in the treatment of this symptom?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image showing excessive facial hair are suggestive of hirsutism. Among the above options, flutamide can be used to manage hirsutism.

However, the use of flutamide should be made with caution as it can cause hepatotoxicity (not commonly used for cosmetic purposes). 

Flutamide is a non-steroidal androgen receptor antagonist used in the treatment of prostatic cancer and in female hirsutism. Other anti-androgens like bicalutamide, nilutamide, and enzalutamide are mainly used with a GnRH analog (such as leuprolide) in managing metastatic prostate cancer. They cannot be used alone in prostate cancer because they increase LH secretion which further causes an increase in serum testosterone secretion. 

Hirsutism is an increased male pattern of hair growth in women of the reproductive age group. It can occur as a benign condition or can be a part of overt virilization caused by excessive androgen production (due to ovarian/adrenal tumors). Other specific causes include PCOS, Cushing's syndrome, etc. Initial therapy is usually with a combination of oral contraceptive pills and, if patients fail to respond, can be changed to anti-androgens like spironolactone, cyproterone acetate, finasteride, and flutamide. Finasteride is a 5-α reductase inhibitor that also reduces prostate size.

Other options:

Option A - Nilutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist used to treat prostate cancer. It is not used in the management of hyperandrogenic states like hirsutism and acne.

Option C- Dutasteride is a 5-α reductase inhibitor that blocks the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Option D- Letrozole is a non-steroidal aromatase inhibitor used in the treatment of breast cancer.

questions.text: 9. A 5-year-old girl is brought to OPD with complaints of upper respiratory tract infections, fever, sandpaper rash over her trunk and extremities. On oral examination, the following image was seen. What is the most probable etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Scarlet fever is the most probable diagnosis. The etiological agent is beta-hemolytic streptococci.

Upper respiratory infection with sandpaper rash and strawberry tongue is suggestive of scarlet fever. Pyrogenic exotoxin (erythrogenic exotoxin) produced by Group A Streptococcus is responsible for scarlet fever. The above image shows the strawberry appearance of the tongue. The tongue is usually coated, and the papillae are swollen, giving the tongue a strawberry appearance.

The images below show the classic sandpaper rash and streptococcal pharyngitis that preceeds the appearance of scarlet fever.





Other options:

Option A: Corynebacterium diphtheriae causes diphtheria and not scarlet fever. 

Option C: HHV 6 causes exanthema subitum, also called the 6th disease, is an acute febrile illness with maculopapular eruptions.

Option D: Erythema infectiosum is caused by parvovirus B19. Clinical features include fever and rash over the face which has a typical slapped cheek appearance. Affected children are afebrile or have a mild fever and do not appear ill.

questions.text: 10. A 43-year-old woman presents with bleeding per vaginum. On transvaginal ultrasound, her endometrial thickness is 20 mm. Fractional curettage shows the following image. She also says her mother died of ovarian cancer 10 years ago and her maternal uncle has been diagnosed with colon cancer 7 years back. What is the diagnostic criteria currently used here and which genes are mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Lynch syndrome, which occurs due to a defect in the MSH2 gene, and the diagnostic criteria for it are the Amsterdam II criteria.

The slide shows adenocarcinoma of the endometrium or endometrial carcinoma, and the history is suggestive of hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) syndrome, or Lynch syndrome, for which the diagnostic criteria are Amsterdam II criteria. The Amsterdam I criteria were used earlier, and now it has been replaced by the Amsterdam II criteria. 

This syndrome is due to defects in DNA mismatch repair genes, with MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2. HNPCC shows familial clustering of cancers at several sites, including the colorectum, endometrium, stomach, ovary, ureters, brain, small bowel, hepatobiliary tract, pancreas, and skin.

Gynecologic malignancies (usually endometrial, ovarian tumors) are often diagnosed before colorectal tumors in female patients with HNPCC.

Pearl PM1256: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

* Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two

* At least two successive generations affected

* At least one case diagnosed before the age of 50 years

* Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded.

* Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

All of the above must be applicable for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC to be made in a family.

questions.text: 11. A 4-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician due to redness in the eyes and tongue for the past 2 days. He also has a history of fever and swelling of his hands and feet during the past week. On examination, desquamative rash and cervical lymphadenopathy are observed. What is the underlying histopathology in this patient's condition?

choices.text: Segmental medial granulomatous inflammation with elastic lamina fragmentation
Segmental, thrombosing inflamation of the vessels
Segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation of large to medium-sized, and small vessels
Necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis involving the capillaries

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of this child is suggestive of Kawasaki disease. The histopathological picture corresponding to Kawasaki disease is segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation of large to medium-sized, and even small, arteries.

Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome) is a self-limiting illness of infancy or childhood. Some patients develop cardiac complications like aneurysms, MI, and sudden death. Treatment involves IV Immunoglobulin and aspirin.

The vascular damage in Kawasaki disease is mainly mediated by the T cells and also by monocytes/macrophages, resulting in a dense transmural infiltrate. This histological picture is also seen in polyarteritis nodosa and Churg–Strauss syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Segmental medial granulomatous inflammation with elastic lamina fragmentation is seen in temporal arteritis 

Option B: Segmental, thrombosing inflammation of the vessels is seen in thrombo-angitis obliterans (Buerger Disease)

Option C: Necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis is seen in granulomatosis with polyangitis.

Pearl PM0191: Kawasaki disease criteria

Diagnostic criteria of Kawasaki disease: 

Fever persisting at least 5 days PLUS

Presence of at least four principal features:

-Changes in extremities

• Acute: erythema of palms, soles; edema of hands, feet

• Subacute: periungual peeling of fingers, toes in weeks 2 and 3

-Polymorphous exanthem

-Bilateral bulbar conjunctival injection without exudate

-Erythema and cracking of lips, strawberry tongue, and/or erythema of oral and pharyngeal mucosa

-Cervical lymphadenopathy (>1.5 cm diameter), usually unilateral

Pearl PM0952: Classification of vasculitis - Modified Chapel Hill classification

questions.text: 12. A 5-year-old child presented with large fontanelles, macroglossia, and delayed developmental milestones. An X-ray of the lower limb is given below. Which of the following radiological findings will be seen in this child?

choices.text: Cystic mass in the intrasellar region

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism, the radiological features of which are an enlarged sella and wormian bones.

The presence of large fontanelles, macroglossia, and delayed developmental milestones, along with the X-ray showing the absence of the distal femoral epiphysis, is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. X-rays of the skull reveal enlarged sella and intersutural (wormian) bones. 

The image below shows an enlarged sella turcica (small arrow) and wormian bones.



Congenital hypothyroidism is the most common preventable cause of intellectual disability. Congenital hypothyroidism is mostly asymptomatic at birth and is detected mainly by the neonatal screening of TSH levels in the first few weeks of life. Clinical features present after maternal thyroxine wanes. 

Thyroid dysgenesis is considered the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in India. The clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism include a puffy face, enlarged fontanelles, macroglossia, prolonged jaundice, lethargy, and a history of poor feeding. The absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses denotes the onset of congenital hypothyroidism. These epiphyses are normally present at birth.

Epiphyseal dysgenesis, wherein there are multiple foci of ossification in the epiphyses, is common. X-rays of the skull reveal enlarged sella, large fontanelles, wide sutures, and intersutural (wormian) bones. 

Image below: The infant on the left with congenital hypothyroidism demonstrates the absence of the distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses, while in the normal infant on the right, the distal femoral epiphysis is present:



The image below shows small upper femoral epiphyses:



Other options:

Option B: Craniopharyngiomas are suprasellar, partially calcified, solid, or mixed solid-cystic benign tumours that arise from remnants of Rathke’s pouch.

Option C: J-shaped sella is a skull radiographic finding in Hurler's syndrome. Hurler's syndrome is a severe type of mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS)-I, caused by a deficiency of α-L-iduronidase.

Option D: Rathke's cleft cysts appear completely cystic with a smooth, thin wall and no calcifications on MRI. They are mostly seen in the intrasellar region.

questions.text:
13. Given below are the 3 Mullerian malformations. What will be the status of paramesonephric ducts, respectively to give rise to these malformations?

* Bicornuate uterus

* Didelphys uterus

* Septate uterus
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option A: Partially fused, unfused, fused

Mullerian malformations  Status of paramesonephric ducts 
1. Didelphys uterus Unfused
2. Bicornuate uterus Partially fused
3. Septate uterus Fused but septum persists


Pearl PM1912: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina


A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: 14. A 54-year-old postmenopausal woman who is on hormone replacement therapy is planned to undergo knee replacement surgery. The correct statement regarding the hormone replacement therapy in this patient is?

choices.text: Continue HRT on the day of surgery
Reduce the dose of HRT on the day of surgery

questions.solution:
Hormone Replacement Therapy should be stopped 4 weeks before surgery since the estrogen in it increase the risk of thromboembolic complications. It is seen that the coagulation function returns to baseline after 4 weeks of stoppage of HRT.

Pearl PM2093: Drugs that can be continued on the day of surgery

* Antihypertensive medications (Exceptions are ACE Inhibitors and ARB) 

* Cardiac medications (e.g., β-blockers, digoxin)

* Antidepressants, anxiolytics, and other psychiatric medications

* Thyroid medications

* Eye drops

* Heartburn or reflux medications

* Narcotic medications

* Anticonvulsants

* Asthma medications

* Steroids (oral and inhaled)

* Statins

* Levodopa

* Mono Amine Oxidase inhibitors are continued when:(1) Anesthesiologist is comfortable with use of MAO-safe procedures (2) Possibility of exacerbation or precipitation of depressive syndrome.

Pearl PM2124: Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery

Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery:

Drug Duration before discontinuation

Topical medications

 Discontinue on the day of surgery

Diuretics (except thiazides) 

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Oral hypoglycemic agents (except SGLT-2 inhibitors)

Discontinue on the day of surgery

SGLT-2 inhibitors

Discontinue 24 hours before elective surgery and 72 hours before intermediate to high risk surgery

Sildenafil 

Discontinue 24 hours before the day of surgery

NSAIDs 

 Discontinue 48 hours before the day of surgery

Warfarin 

Discontinue 4 days before surgery (except for patients having cataract surgery without a bulbar block)

Short-acting Insulins 

 Discontinued (except when given by a continuous pump)

Thienopyridines (e.g., clopidogrel, ticlopidine) 

 Discontinued (Except in cataract surgery, patients with metallic/drug-eluting stents)

Aspirin 

 Discontinued 3 days before the surgery (except in patients with prior PCI, coronary artery disease and stroke)

MAO Inhibitors

 Discontinued 2 weeks prior

questions.text: 15. You are evaluating a cyanotic newborn with an echocardiogram showing pulmonic stenosis involving the root of the pulmonary artery. Which developmental structure's defective maturation is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
This newborn is found to have pulmonic stenosis involving the root of the pulmonary artery. The structure which gives rise to the root of the pulmonary artery is the truncus arteriosus which is marked as '4' in the given image.

Structures marked:

* Sinus venosus

* Atrium

* Bulbus cordis

* Truncus arteriosus

The heart tube begins to bend by day 23. This bending creates the cardiac loop which is completed by day 28. The fate of various structures formed as a result of this bending is as follows:



Given below are the heart tube and their derivatives:

 Part of the heart tube Derivative structure in the heart

Bulbus cordis

  • Proximal 1/3 

 

  • Middle 1/3 (conus cordis)

 

  • Distal 1/3 (truncus arteriosus)

 

  • Trabeculated part of right ventricle

 

  • Outflow tract of right and left ventricles

 

  • Root and proximal portions of aorta and pulmonary artery
Primitive ventricle
  • Trabeculated part of the left ventricle
Primitive atrium
  • The common atrium that splits to right and left atrium

questions.text: 16. A 23-year-old G2P1 lady with a previous history of cesarean section was found to have placenta accreta on ultrasonography. Imperfect development of which layer leads to this condition?
questions.solution:
Imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer, which is marked as 1 in the given image, leads to placenta accreta.

The other structures marked in the image are: 2 and 4 are cytotrophoblast and 3 is inner syncytiotrophoblast. 

Placenta accreta is a condition in which the placenta is directly attached to the myometrium either partially or completely without any intervening decidua. This abnormal attachment to myometrium is due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer.

The definitive placenta consists of the chorionic plate on the fetal aspect and a basal plate on the maternal aspect with the intervillous space between them. The structures in each of these parts are as follows:



Morbidly adherent placenta (MAP) occurs when the placenta fails to detach from the uterine wall, and these include: 

* Placenta accreta – placental villi adhere to the myometrium

* Placenta increta – villi grow into the myometrium

* Placenta percreta – villi extend through the myometrium and may reach or breach the serosa

The image given below shows different types of morbidly adherent placenta.



Risk factors for MAP include prior cesarean delivery, placenta previa, prior uterine surgeries like hysterotomy, prior curettage, and endometrial ablation. Ultrasound imaging, color Doppler, and MRI have all been helpful in the diagnosis of MAP during pregnancy.

Management:

* Partial placenta accreta - placental tissue is removed, and bleeding areas are oversewed.

* Total placenta accreta - 

* Parous women - hysterectomy is done 

* If the patient desires to have a child, the umbilical cord is cut close to its base so that the placenta left behind gets autolyzed

* If MAP invades the bladder, hysterectomy and partial cystectomy are required.

questions.text: 17. A 45-year-old P4L4 woman presented with abnormal uterine bleeding and lower abdominal discomfort. She also gives a history of an incomplete abortion for which she had to undergo a D&C procedure. On examination, the uterus appears to be uniformly enlarged, corresponding to a 12-week gestation. The adnexa is free. You make a diagnosis and make the patient undergo a total hysterectomy. The images below show the transverse section of uterus and histology of the specimen. Which of the following is not a risk factor for the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, the gross specimen, histological slide, all point to the diagnosis of adenomyosis and OCPs are not risk factors for its development.

The history of a 45 yr old multiparous woman with a history of vigorous curettage, with complaints, of AUB, along with an enlarged uterus are points in favour of a diagnosis of adenomyosis. The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with a spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of haemorrhage. The H&E stained specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis (Endometriosis interna):

* Aetiology: Prior curettage, prior uterine surgery, repeated childbirth, excess of estrogen, intake of tamoxifen (SERM) (option D)

* Clinical features:

* Multiparous females >40 years (option A, option B)

* Most common symptom: Menorrhagia > Dysmenorrhea

* Pelvic discomfort, backache, dyspareunia

* Per-Vaginal: Symmetrical enlargement of the uterus (corresponding to <12-14 weeks of pregnancy)

* Bimanual examination: Halban’s sign: Tender, softened uterus

* Diagnosis:

* It is mainly clinical

* Diagnostic hysteroscopy with curettage

* Management of adenomyosis

* Total Hysterectomy (Treatment of choice)

* Localized excision/ Levonorgestrel containing IUCD is tried in younger women

questions.text: 18. The neonate of a woman from a rural area has the condition shown in the image below. The neonate was healthy for the first 2-3 days after birth, following which he developed progressive difficulty in taking feeds. She had a normal delivery at home but had not received any antenatal care. The possible cause is _________.

choices.text: Inhibition of presynaptic release of inhibitory neurotransmitter
Inhibition of post-synaptic release of inhibitory neurotransmitter
Inhibition of presynaptic release of excitatory neurotransmitter
Inhibition of post-synaptic release of excitatory neurotransmitter

questions.solution:
The cause of tetany in this scenario is the inhibition of presynaptic release of inhibitory neurotransmitter.

The given image shows a neonate with opisthotonus, and progressive difficulty in taking feeds indicates lock-jaw. The history indicates that the mother was not vaccinated during pregnancy. All these features are suggestive of neonatal tetanus.

Clostridium tetani produces an exotoxin tetanospasmin. It is a plasmid-coded, heat-labile toxin, which enters the motor nerve endings of glycinergic interneurons and γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) secreting neurons. The toxin peptide degrades synaptobrevin, a protein required for the attachment of neurotransmitter vesicles on the presynaptic membrane before its release.

The motor neurons are not inhibited as the release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and GABA is blocked. This causes hyperreflexia, muscle spasms, and spastic paralysis result.

Blockade of action of neurotransmitters at post-synaptic terminal is a mechanism of strychnine poisoning presenting similar to tetany. Inhibition of presynaptic release of excitatory neurotransmitters (acetylcholine) is seen in Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome.



Pearl PM2032: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

* Bordetella pertusis

* Bacillus anthracis

* Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin

* Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

* Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

* Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)

* Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)

* Clostridium difficile

* Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S

* Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: 19. A newborn is delivered via cesarean section due to fetal distress. Shortly after birth, the infant exhibits bilious vomiting and fails to pass meconium. On physical examination, the abdomen appears distended, and hypoactive bowel sounds are noted. X-ray abdomen reveals a double bubble sign. Identify the radiological finding shown in the image, obtained on barium study.
questions.solution:
A newborn presents with bilious vomiting, failure to pass meconium, and abdominal distension, leading to a diagnosis of duodenal atresia indicated by the double bubble sign on the X-ray. The radiological finding obtained on the barium study is a windsock deformity.

In Type I duodenal atresia (duodenal web), the mucosa and submucosa form a thin, distensible membrane that may contain a small central aperture. Repeated peristaltic forces cause this membrane to balloon distally, producing a sac-like intraluminal projection known as a windsock web. On contrast study, this appears as a windsock deformity.

Duodenal atresia is the blockade of the duodenum caused due to the failure of the vacuolization of the solid duodenum. It is usually identified during the prenatal ultrasound, where it shows the presence of a double bubble sign. If the atresia goes unnoticed during the prenatal period, the babies usually present with bilious vomiting soon after birth. This is because the obstruction is distal to the ampulla of Vater in most cases. Non-bilious vomiting would favour a more proximal obstruction, such as in congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

The plain abdominal radiograph shows a typical double-bubble sign:



Three types of duodenal atresia are described as follows:

Type I: most common; mucosal web with intact muscle wall (so-called windsock deformity) Type II: two ends separated by a fibrous cord, but muscle continuity present Type III: complete separation of two ends with a gap within the duodenum



Intestinal obstruction from atresias, more common in the jejunum, presents with hypoactive bowel sounds, abdominal distension, and bilious emesis. Proximal atresia shows less distension but significant emesis, with air-fluid levels and absent distal gas on radiographs. Distal atresia causes more distension. Initial management includes nasogastric decompression, IV fluids, and parenteral nutrition. Evaluation for associated anomalies includes echocardiography, renal ultrasound, and chest/spine radiographs. The surgical treatment is Kimura's duodenoduodenostomy.

Other options:

Option A: The string sign on the barium enema is in ileocecal tuberculosis.



Option B: Rigler sign is also called a double-wall sign which is seen on an abdominal radiograph when gas is lining both sides of the bowel wall, observed in pneumoperitoneum, as shown below.



Option D: Apple peel deformity, also known as Christmas tree Deformity is seen in type IIIb jejunoileal atresia where there is a large mesenteric gap between atretic segments and the distal loop gets retrograde blood supply from the ileocolic or right colic artery.



Pearl PM1804: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign



 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 



 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign



 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 



 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign



 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.



Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 



 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.



 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.



 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).



Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: 20. A 27-year-old female patient with right iliac fossa pain, is found to have a positive UPT and the following sign is seen on imaging. Which other condition may be associated with this radiological sign?
questions.solution:
The image shows a characteristic ring of fire pattern seen on transvaginal sonography with colour doppler in tubal ectopic pregnancy. This vascular pattern and finding on TVS is also seen with corpus luteum cysts, although the wall is less echogenic compared to a tubal ectopic. 

The fallopian tubes are the most common site for ectopic pregnancy. It should be suspected in any female of reproductive age presenting with an acute abdomen, and a urine pregnancy test should be performed for all such patients. Tubal ectopic pregnancy may be diagnosed by transvaginal ultrasound (TVS), which will show the tubal ring sign, also called the bagel sign or blob sign. It refers to the appearance of a gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring. Doppler imaging reveals the flow of blood in the periphery of the sac, which gives the ring of fire appearance.



Other options:

Option A: Molar pregnancy is associated with snowstorm appearance on ultrasound.

Option B: Dichorioinic twin pregnancy is associated with twin peak or lambda sign on ultrasound.

Option D: Intrauterine death is associated with Spalding sign on ultrasound.

Pearl PM2262: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.



 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.



 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.



 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.



 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.



 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 



 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.



 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 



 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.



 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.



 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.



 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.
